thread.title: Even the most hardcore StarWars fans probably don’t know this (7 photos)
thread.title_full: Even the most hardcore StarWars fans probably don’t know this (7 photos)

author: Jeff
title: Even the most hardcore StarWars fans probably don’t know this (7 photos)
text:
View as Slideshow 1 
VFX artist Todd Vaziri was working on Rogue One last year when someone pointed out to him something mind blowing. He made a post on his blog FXRant where he very correctly shocks Star Wars fans minds by pointing out that the climactic scene of the original film, where Luke and the rest of the rebel pilots fly into the Death Star’s infamous trench is not where you think it is. 2 
The place everyone assumed the rebels attack is the horizontal (or East/West) trench. 
However, the trench attacked is actually one of the vertical (North/South) trenches. They flat out show you this in Star Wars, but it was ignored by fans everywhere. 3 GIF 
From FXRant: “The scene of General Dodonna briefing the Rebel troops contains some computer graphics displayed at the front of the room. As Dodonna describes the challenges ahead, the audience can see quite clearly that the trench that contains the exhaust port is perpendicular to the equator. It was there the whole time. 4 GIF 
Still not buying it? Compare the two trenches in the film. 
Here we can see the Millennium Falcon being pulled into the Death Star via tractor beam. This is at the horizontal trench. Notice the lights, the massive size. Notice the hanger bays which house hundreds of tie fighters inside as well as could fit the Falcon with tons of room to spare. 5 
Now compare it to the climactic trench run (North/South). Advertisement 6 GIF 
It is small. X-Wings and Tie Fighters are cramped. There are no lights. In fact it seems to be more utilitarian, exactly where an exhaust port might be found. 
BOOM. 7 GIF 
Also, as long as we are blowing minds, have you ever noticed that Darth Vader’s outer helmet is blowing all over the place in this scene from Empire? 
Via
